bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 10, 1896

div1.p: Reed writes concerning experimentation. He describes his return from Key West, and mosquito attacks.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 10, 1896

opener.dateline:
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D.C.,
August 10, '96.

div1.p:
Here I am,
once more, at the very centre
of civilization, with bones un-
broken and health greatly
improved. Many, many thanks
to your kind care and gen-
erous hospitality for this
condition of affairs- My week's
stay at Key West seems now
like some bright dream;
and I long to fall asleep
in order that it may again
come back to me!
Instead, I find that I must
once more take up the mo-
notonous thread of daily ex-
istence and amuse myself
with simian society as
best I can- You can rest
assured that I lost no
time in trying my virus on
one of these young apes, whose
temperature, 48 hours after,
is reported as 105°- Have
already begun the search for the
“bugs” and expect a rare find!
I trust that you received
my note written on Board
the City of Richmond & that my
valuable memoranda, which
were left in the table-drawer
to the right of the door, are
now on their way northward.
Of course, you want to know
something of my return
journey along the Keys; and
whether you really are pining
for this information or not,
I feel it my duty to enlighten
you as to the advantages
and beauties of this “route
to the Eastward” -- this fas-
cinating inward route
along the Keys, where
the water is smooth and
the mango grows-
Well, I must, as an honest
historian, tell you that the water
was smooth, hardly broken by
a ripple; and that there were
colors playing on it worthy
of an artist's brush-

But, -- in order to enjoy this,
one must be awakened at
5 a.m. by the rattle of chains,
and amid a chorus of orders,
as the boat leaves her Pier.
I had intended sleeping
till 7 a.m., but instead found
myself on deck at 6 a.m.,
just in time to get a last
glympse at your beautiful
Island home, which was
softly fading over the waters
green! And then came
the Keys, the famous
Florida Keys -- some of them
beautiful enough, I'm sure,
to be the Keys to a better
world! I feasted mine
eyes on them, and thought, “well
my good Doctor Kean was
not far wrongt when he
advised this journey, although
I should have preferred a
later rising”! 7.30 am, --
breakfast announced --
now, my dear doctor, don't say
anything about it, -- not for the
world -- but if you do come
this way, don't forget to carry
your breakfast! The latter
was simply atrocious & with-
out excuse! I was delighted
to get a little oatmeal porridge --
and some bread & butter. How
I longed for an alligator Pear!
When I had recovered from
my disappointment, I found
that the rest of the day passed
pleasantly enough -- only oc-
casionally an explosive “damn”
would escape, when I thought of
that early pretension to a break-
fast. We came to anchor in
Biscayne Bay just at Sun-
set -- the scene a really beau-
tiful one -- and as I was
tired and in need of sleep,
I turned in early, occupying
a state-room on the other side
of the boat, so as to enjoy
the breeze. Horrors! I was
just beginning to dose, when
an Army of mosquitoes arrived
with banners flying and voices
attuned to sweetest music-
I smiled & reached for my
little bottle of 8 pts. Camphorae,
which you were kind enough
to suggest as a shield against
the hungry insect. Don't under-
stand me to say that Camphor
is not very good for somethings,
especially when mixed with other
things -- but as a protection
against Florida Mosquitoes -- why
my dear doctor, when they got
the first whiff of it, they only
sang the louder, & immediately
went off and told their rela-
tives about it! They swarmed
all over me and begged for
Camphor and with tears of
joy & happiness in their little
blues eyes, they bit me un-
mercifully, while they laughed
& sang! I stood it just 5
minutes, and then grabbing
my apparel & baggage, I beat
a hasty retreat to Cabin 47,
where I knew there was a
Mosquitoe-bar. Even after I
was secures behind the net, they
came in in troops & begged me
for “more of that delicious perfume”
and when I told them that it was
highly recommended by an Army
Medical Officer against mosquitoes, they laughed
& shouted, till I verily believe
somed of them strained their
little waist-bands! Don't recommend
spts. Camphorae for the “inland
route”, or was it, after all,
a joke? Say -- “honor bright”?
I have already forgiven you!
When life is young and the spir-
-its bouyant, early rising is
said to be a health giving
procedure and recommended
as conducive to greater pecun-
iary rewards & c- Doubtless
time enough- I shan't stop to
dispute it- But when old
age has come & the blood-
current slackens apace, there
are other things which har-
monize better with one's thoughts.
This, by the way, however --
Thursday morning, I was awakened
at 3.30 o'clock, “because”, as the
Cabin boy put it, “the other Capt-
ain” (meaning the Captain of the tender
Biscayne) “has a way of starting
off without telling anybody about
it”! This was interesting! It
is not necessary to say that I lost
no time in transferring myself
and baggage to the “Biscayne”-
She did haul off promptly at
4 o'clock in the midst of a
terrific rain & thunder-storm.
I was beginning to worry just
a bit for our safety, but just
then the boat stopped, and when
I saw that the Captain had
dropped a nigger & a small
boat overboard, in order to put
out a light on a beer-keg (used
us a buoy,) my courage rose,
and I rather enjoyed the whistling
of the wind and the flashes of
lightning- Rounding into the
mouth of Miami River, a little
before 5 o'clock, and opposite
the point where Hagler's new
Hotel is being constructed, the
scene was tropical and beau-
tiful beyond description-
I felt quite repaid for my
hardships -- but when, a few
minutes later, I found myself lit-
erally herded in a common coach
with a crowd of perspiring mor-
tals who hadn't had a bath for
a year, my anger rose and I
almost said something pro-
fane! 2 eating stations advertiz-
ed en route, but at neither was
food provided that one could partake
of -- arrived at Jacksonville nearly
famished- As yet, my dear doctor,
until things have become a little straight-
ened out & the edges smoothed down, I would
advise against the “Eastern Route.”
Found Mrs. Reed & children very well
in spite of the intensely hot weather
here- To my horrors, also, found that
Mrs. R. likes the mango! pronounces
it a most delicious fruit, & insists upon
having her share! I have yielded, but
not with a good grace. Mrs. R. is delight-
ed with the guava paste- She joins me
in warmest regards to Mrs. Kean & your
self & thanks both of you so much for your kind
thoughtfulness in sending the aforesaid del-
icacies. I have written this, in the midst
of untold interruptions- Whether you can
get sense out it, I very much doubt. Again
my dear Doctor, expressing my warmest thanks to your
dear wife & self for all that you did to to make my visit
so pleasant, & with best love for dear little Martha.
div1.closer: I remain, sincerely yours, Walter Reed.
